page.title: 2.7.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Prior to this point, you have worked primarily with equations in one and two variables. In this lesson, you will shift your attention to inequalities. You will interpret, write, and find solutions to inequalities in one variable.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Write inequalities that represent the constraints in a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.7.1: Understanding Inequality Symbols
  • 2.7.2: Identifying Constraints in Inequalities
  • 2.7.2: Self Check
  • 2.7.3: Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints
  • 2.7.3: Self Check
  • 2.7.4: Writing More Inequalities

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.7.5: Practice
  • 2.7.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 2.7.1: Understanding Inequality Symbols
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

  1. Match each inequality to the meaning of a symbol within it.
    1. \( h>50 \)
    2. \( h \leq 20 \)
    3. \( 30 \geq h \)

    1. less than or equal to
    2. greater than
    3. greater than or equal to

Enter your answer here:

Check your answers:

  1. 2, \(h > 50\): "greater than"
  2. 1, \(h\;\leq\;20\): "less than or equal to"
  3. 3, \(30\;\geq\;h\): "greater than or equal to"

  1. Is 25 a solution to any of the inequalities? Which one(s)?

Enter your answer here

Yes; 25 is a solution to \( 30 ≥ h \) because 30 is greater than or equal to 25.


  1. Is 40 a solution to any of the inequalities? Which one(s)?

Enter your answer here:

No; 40 is not a solution to any of the inequalities because 40 does not make any of the inequalities true when substituted in for \( h \).


  1. Is 30 a solution to any of the inequalities? Which one(s)?

Enter your answer here:

Yes; 30 is a solution to \( 30 ≥ h \) because, while \( 30 > 30 \) is not a true statement, \( 30 = 30 \) is a true statement.

page.title: 2.7.2: Identifying Constraints in Inequalities
page.contents:
Activity

Seniors in a high school student council are trying to develop a budget for the Senior Dance. The revenue from ticket sales needs to cover the cost of the meals and entertainment and also make a profit of at least $200 to be contributed to the school. 

Here is some information they have gathered:

  • Last year, 120 people attended. It was a success and is expected to be even bigger this year. Up to 200 people will attend.
  • There needs to be at least 1 chaperone for every 20 students.
  • The ticket price cannot exceed $20 per person.

Here are some inequalities the seniors wrote about the situation. Each letter stands for one quantity in the situation. Determine what is meant by each letter.

  1. \( t ≤ 20 \)
  2. \( 120 ≤ p ≤ 200 \)
  3. \( pt - m ≥ 200 \)
  4. \( c \geq \frac{p}{20} \)

Enter your answers to questions 1–4 here:

Your answers may vary, but here are some sample responses to compare your answers.

Sample response (an interpretation of the meaning of each letter and an interpretation of the mathematical statement are included):

  1. \( t ≤ 20 \)
  2. \( 120 ≤ p ≤ 200 \)
  3. \( pt - m ≥ 200 \)
  4. \( c \geq \frac{p}{20} \)

Extending Your Thinking

Kiran says we should add the constraint \( t ≥ 0 \).

  1. What is the reasoning behind this constraint?
  2. What other “natural constraint” like this should be added?

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answers:

  1. We can't have a negative ticket price.
  2. By the same reasoning we might want to include \(m\;\geq\;0\). Note that the other variables should also be greater than or equal to 0, but those conditions are already implied by the existing constraints.

page.title: 2.7.2 Self Check
page.contents:
A zookeeper feeds the tigers a meal of rabbits and chickens. The average rabbit weighs 4 pounds, and the average chicken weighs 5 pounds. Each tiger must eat at least 15 pounds of meat per day.

The zookeeper writes the inequality \( 4x + 5y ≥ 15 \) to represent a tiger’s daily diet.

What is meant by the letter \( y \) in the inequality above?

answer.answer_text: The number of rabbits a tiger eats daily
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The number of rabbits a tiger eats daily is represented by \(x\). The answer is the number of chickens a tiger eats daily.

answer.answer_text: The average weight of a rabbit
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The average weight of a rabbit is 4 pounds. The answer is the number of chickens a tiger eats daily.

answer.answer_text: The number of chickens a tiger eats daily
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The letter \(y\) represents the number of chickens a tiger eats daily.

answer.answer_text: The average weight of a chicken
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The average weight of a chicken is 5 pounds. The answer is the number of chickens a tiger eats daily.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 2.7.2 Additional Resources
page.contents:
Translate to an Inequality

To translate English sentences into inequalities, we need to recognize the phrases that indicate the inequality. Some words are easy, like “more than” and “less than.” But others are not as obvious. The table shows some common phrases that indicate inequalities.

> > ≥ ≥ < < ≤ ≤

is greater than

is more than

is larger than

exceeds

is greater than or equal to

is at least

is no less than

is the minimum

is less than

is smaller than

has fewer than

is lower than

is less than or equal to

is at most

is no more than

is the maximum


Example


Translate each phrase to an inequality.

Twenty-seven less than x \(\underbrace{is\;at\;least}\) 48
\(x-17\geq48\)

"is at least" means \( \geq \)
5 more than z \(\underbrace{is\;lower\;than}\) 52

\(z + 5 < 52\)

"is at least" means \( \geq \)

Try It: Translate to an Inequality 

Translate the following sentences into inequalities.

  1. Nineteen less than \( p \) is no less than 47.
  2. Four more than \( a \) is at most 15.

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution 

Here is how to translate these sentences into inequalities:

  1. Solution: \( p - 19 ≥ 47 \)
  2. Solution: \( a + 4 ≤ 15 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.7.3: Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints
page.contents:
Activity

An elevator car in a skyscraper can hold at most 15 people. For safety reasons, each car can carry a maximum of 1,500 kg. On average, an adult weighs 70 kg and a child weighs 35 kg. Assume that each person carries 4 kg of gear with them.

  1. Write as many equations and inequalities as you can think of to represent the constraints in this situation. Be sure to specify the meaning of any letters that you use. (Avoid using the letters \( z \), \( m \), or \( g \).)

Enter your answer here:

Answers vary. Here are some sample responses::

  • \( p ≤ 15 \), where \( p \) represents the number of people in an elevator car.
  • \( a + c ≤ 15 \), where \( a \) represents the number of adults and \( c \) represents the number of children in an elevator car.
  • \( w ≤ 1,500 \), where \( w \) represents the weight in kilograms in one elevator car.
  • \( w = 70a + 35c + 4a + 4c \)
  • \( 70a + 35c + 4a + 4c ≤ 1,500 \)
  • \( 74a + 39c ≤ 1,500 \)

  1. Trade your work with a partner and read each other’s equations and inequalities.
  • Explain to your partner what you think their statements mean, and listen to their explanation of yours.
  • Make adjustments to your equations and inequalities so that they are communicated more clearly.
  1. Rewrite your equations and inequalities so that they would work for a different building where:
  • an elevator car can hold at most \( z \) people
  • each car can carry a maximum of \( m \) kilograms
  • each person carries \( d \) kg of gear

Enter your answer here:

Answers vary. Sample Responses:
  • \( p ≤ z \)
  • \( a + c ≤ z \)
  • \( w ≤ m \)
  • \( w = 70a + 35c + da + dc \)
  • \( 70a + 35c + da + dc ≤ m \)
  • \( (70 + d)a + (35 + d)c ≤ m \)

Video: Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints Solution 

Watch the following video to further explain the solution to the activity you just completed.

page.title: 2.7.4: Writing More Inequalities
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Han has a budget of $25 to buy grapes. Write inequalities to represent the number of pounds of grapes that Han could buy in each situation:

  • Grapes cost $1.99 per pound.
  • Grapes cost $2.49 per pound.
  • Grapes cost $\(c\) per pound.

Enter your answer to the questions here:

Let \( g \) represent the number of pounds of grapes.

  • \( 1.99g ≤ 25 \)
  • \( 2.49g ≤ 25 \)
  • \( cg ≤ 25 \)

page.title: 2.7.3 Self Check
page.contents: Serena is running a juice shop. Oranges cost $2 per pound. She can spend at most $64 per day on oranges. If \( p \) represents the number of pounds of oranges Serena can buy per day, which of the following inequalities is true?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The statement \( 2p ≤ 64 \) means she can spend at most $64 at $2 per pound.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This statement needs to include spending exactly $64. The answer is \( 2p ≤ 64 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The cost cannot be greater than $64. The answer is \( 2p ≤ 64 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The cost cannot exceed $64. The answer is \( 2p ≤ 64 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 2.7.3 Additional Resources
page.contents:
Applications with Linear Inequalities

Many real-life situations require us to solve inequalities. The method we will use to solve applications with linear inequalities is very much like the one we used when we solved applications with equations.

We will read the problem and make sure we understand all the words. Next, we will identify what we are looking for and assign a variable to represent it. We will restate the problem in one sentence to make it easy to translate into an inequality. 

Example 

Dawn won a mini-grant of $4,000 to buy tablet computers for her classroom. The tablets she would like to buy cost $254.12 each, including tax and delivery. Write an inequality to represent the maximum number of tablets Dawn can buy.

Solution

Step 1. Read the problem.

Step 2. Identify what you are looking for.

the maximum number of tablets Dawn can buy

Step 3. Name what you are looking for.

Choose a variable to represent that quantity.

Let \( n= \) the number of tablets.

Step 4. Translate. Write a sentence that gives the information to find it.

$254.12 times the number of tablets is no more than $4,000.

Translate into an inequality.

\( 254.12n ≤ 4000 \)

Try It: Applications with Linear Inequalities

  1. Angie has $20 to spend on juice boxes for her son’s preschool picnic. Each pack of juice boxes costs $2.63. Write an inequality to represent the maximum number of packs, \( p \), she can buy.
  2. Daniel wants to surprise his girlfriend with a birthday party at her favorite restaurant. It will cost $42.75 per person for dinner, including tip and tax. His budget for the party is $500. Write an inequality to represent the maximum number of people, \( n \), Daniel can have at the party.

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is a way to write an inequality for each situation:

  1. \( 2.63p ≤ 20 \)
  2. \( 42.75n ≤ 500 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.7.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1–2, use the following passage:

A runner is training for a marathon. She runs more than 4 days each week. Each day, she runs between 12 and 15 miles. The marathon is 3 months away at the most.

1. What does the inequality \(d > 4\) represent?

Correct! the number of days the runner runs each week

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the number of days the runner runs each week. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. What does the inequality \(12\;\leq\;m\;\leq\;15\) represent?

Correct! the number of miles the runner runs each day

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the number of miles the runner runs each day. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 3-8, write an inequality to represent the constraint given.


3. There are less than 4 patients, p, in the waiting room.

Correct! \(p\;<\;4\;\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(p\;<\;4\;\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. There are no more than 6 cats, c, in the yard.

Correct! \( c < 6 \)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(c<6\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

5. There are no less than 7 markers, m, in the drawer.

Correct! \(m\;\geq\;7\;\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(m\;\geq\;7\;\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6. The basket has between 12 and 19 eggs, e.

Correct! \(12 < e < 19 \)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(12 < e < 19\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. The total sales of tickets to a show is more than $68. An adult ticket, a, costs $8 and a children’s ticket, c, is $3.

Correct! \(8a + 3c > 68 \)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(8a + 3c > 68\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. There needs to be at least 1 pound of clay, c, for every 4 students, s.

Correct! \(c\;\geq\;\frac s4\;\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(p\;\geq\;\frac s4\;\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 9-11, use the following passage:

A doctor sees between 7 and 12 patients each day. On Mondays and Tuesdays, the appointment times are 15 minutes. On Wednesdays and Thursdays, they are 30 minutes long. On Fridays, they are one hour long. The doctor works for no more than 8 hours a day. Here are some inequalities that represent this situation.

\(0.25\;\leq\;y\;\leq\;1\)            \(7\;\leq\;x\;\leq\;12\)           \(xy\;\leq\;8\)

9. What does the variable x represent?

Correct! the number of patients the doctor sees each day

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the number of patients the doctor sees each day. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

10. What does the variable x represent?

Correct! the part of an hour that each appointment lasts

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the part of an hour that each appointment lasts. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

11. What does the expression \(xy\) in the last inequality mean in this situation?

Correct! the total time the doctor spends working with patients each day

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 2.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is the total time the doctor spends working with patients each day. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 12-14, use the following passage:

Arnav wants to build a dog house. He makes a list of the materials needed:

  • At least 60 square feet of plywood for the surfaces
  • At least 36 feet of wood planks for the frame of the dog house
  • Between 1 and 2 quarts of paint

Arnav's budget is $65. Plywood costs $0.70 per square foot, planks of wood cost $0.10 per foot, and paint costs $8 per quart.


12. Which inequality represents the square feet of plywood needed?

Correct! \(p\;\geq\;60\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(p\;\geq\;60\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

13. Which inequality represents the number of wood planks needed?

Correct! \(w\;\geq\;36\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(w\;\geq\;36\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

14. Which inequality represents the number of quarts of paint needed?

Correct! \(1\;\leq\;q\;\leq\;2\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 2.7.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(1\;\leq\;q\;\leq\;2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.7.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Write inequalities that represent the constraints in a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.7.1: Understanding Inequality Symbols
    • In this activity, you recalled the meaning of inequality symbols (<, >, ≤, and ≥) and the meaning of "solutions to an inequality." You were reminded that an inequality in one variable can have a range of values that make the statement true. You also explored the value that is at the boundary of an inequality and consider whether it is or isn't a solution to an inequality.
  • 2.7.2: Identifying Constraints in Inequalities
    • In this activity, you were prompted to interpret several inequalities that represent the constraints in a situation. To explain what the letters in the inequalities mean in the given context, you could not simply match the numbers in the verbal descriptions and those in the inequalities. You worked to attend carefully to the symbols and any operations, and reason both quantitatively and abstractly.
  • 2.7.2: Self Check
  • 2.7.3: Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints
    • Previously, you interpreted given inequalities and made sense of them in terms of a situation. In this activity, you wrote inequalities to represent the constraints in a situation. You identified key quantities and relationships, and thought about ways to represent them.
  • 2.7.3: Self Check
  • 2.7.4: Writing More Inequalities
  • In this activity, you wrote inequalities to represent the number of pounds of grapes that a person could buy in a given situation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.7.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
